description: From French piastre, from Italian piastra (“plate of wood or metal; coin”), probably from Latin emplastra.

entries.meaning: (now historical) A Spanish or Spanish-American coin and unit of currency, originally worth eight real.
examples: The Silkes, Velvets, Cloth of gold, and Tissue, Pyasters, Chicqueenes and Sultanies, which is gold and silver, they unloaded in foure and twentie houres, was wonderfull [...].

entries.meaning: (historical) A form of currency formerly used in the French-speaking parts of Canada.
(historical) A form of currency formerly used in French Indochina.
(historical) A form of currency originally used in the Ottoman Empire.
(historical) A form of currency formerly used in Cyprus.
A form of currency currently used as a subunit in the Middle Eastern countries of Egypt, Jordan (partly including Palestine), Lebanon, South Sudan, Sudan, and Syria.
